Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineering and Computing in Rehabilitation and Assisitve Technologies

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program, Engineering and Computing in Rehabilitation and Assistive Technologies (ECRAT) at Cleveland State University, offers an immersive experience in rehabilitation research that will help motivate and prepare a diverse group of students to pursue careers in rehabilitation engineering and assistive technology. The number of people with disabilities will increase in the United States in the coming decades due to an aging population and advances in medicine that extend the lives of people with chronic diseases (e.g., diabetes) and victims of traumatic accidents (e.g., car crashes). Despite the national need for rehabilitation technology, opportunities to enter the field of rehabilitation engineering are limited for many students and there is a critical need to increase and diversify the population of students equipped to pursue careers in rehabilitation engineering and assistive technology. Therefore the overall objectives of this project are to: 1) Immerse a diverse group of undergraduate engineering and computer science students in the challenges of developing technology to restore daily function to people who have limited ability to move their arms and legs. 2) Motivate students to pursue future opportunities in rehabilitation and assistive technology. 3) Empower students to succeed in careers in rehabilitation and assistive technology.

Over a three year period, the ECRAT program will engage undergraduates students in a 10-week intensive, original and creative hands-on summer research and professional development/training experience centered around integrated learning communities that surround REU students with their peers, their mentors, medical professionals, and people with disabilities. The project's outcomes will be a diverse group of students motivated and prepared to pursue careers in rehabilitation and assistive technology and a structured program in immersing students in rehabilitation research that can be disseminated across the country.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of the project were to:

  1. Immerse a diverse group of undergraduate engineering and computer science students in the challenges of developing technology to restore daily function to people who have limited ability to move their arms and legs.
  2. Motivate students to pursue future opportunities in rehabilitation and assistive technology.
  3. Empower students to succeed in careers in rehabilitation and assistive technology.

 

The major activities of the project include recruiting 36 undergraduate students in three cohorts to Cleveland State University (CSU). The students spent 10 weeks at CSU working alongside faculty members and graduate students participating in rehabilitation engineering and assistive technology research. While the REU students were at CSU they participated in research activities, attended weekly seminars and visited a variety of places that provide assistance and information to and for people with mobility challenges.

 

36 students participated in the program out of 887 applicants over three years. 31 students from institutions outside CSU were supported by the REU program. 5 CSU students were supported by CSU?s Operation STEM program which offers a bridge program and mentoring for primarily first generation college students. Of the 31 students supported by NSF, 6 have disabilities (19%), 6 are African American (19%), 8 are Hispanic (26%), 20 are women (65%), 1 is a Pacific Islander (3%), 1 is a Native American (3%), and 20 come from non-R1 institutions (65%).

 

Students from the 2017 Cohort who have graduated are now (9 of 10 students have responded with current position)

  • Employed by Genentech -- related field to REU program 
  • Completed MS in Biomedical Engineering at the University of Michigan and employed by Teleflex -- related field to REU program
  • Enrolled in PhD in Biomedical Engineering at Cleveland State University  - related field to REU program 
  • Completed MSE in Bioinnovation and Design at Johns Hopkins University and employed by Johnson and Johnson - related field to REU program 
  • Enrolled in PhD in Mechanical Engineering and Human Robot Interaction  - related field to REU program 
  • Beginning medical school at Creighton University after working for Stryker Instruments - related field to REU program 
  • Employed by Raytheon 
  • Employed by Echo Global Logistics 
  • Recently graduated and searching for employment in industry 

Students from the 2018 Cohort who have graduated are now (9 of 9 students have responded with current position)

  • Employed as a Biomedical Engineer by the Fort Wayne VA Medical Center -- related field to REU
  • Enrolled in MS in Prosthetics and Orthotics at Baylor College of Medicine 
  • Employed by General Electric HealthCare -- related field to REU 
  • Employed by Envoltz, LLC
  • Employed by Sedron Technologies 
  • Founder of Momentix Toys
  • Employed by L3Harris Technologies 
  • Employed by IRIS USA 
  • Recently graduated and searching for employment in industry 

Students from the 2019 cohort who have graduated are now (6 of 8 students have responded with current position)

  • Enrolled in MA in Disability Studies at University of Leeds  -- related field to REU
  • Enrolled in PhD program in Biomedical Engineering at University of North Carolina/NC State -- related field to REU 
  • Enrolled in MS in Bioengineering at University of Colorado Denver Center for Inclusive Design and Engineering -- related field to REU
  • Employed by the United Illuminating Company
  • Employed by Amica Insurance

Last Modified: 06/24/2021
Modified by: Eric Schearer
